section.title: About &name-icinga;
section.para: &name-icinga; is a monitoring system checking hosts and services you specify and notifying you when things go wrong and when they recover. It runs on multiple &name-linux; distributions (including &name-fedora;, &name-ubuntu;, and &name-opensuse;) as well as several Unix platforms (including &name-solaris; and &name-hp;). The systems to be monitored can be nearly anything connected to a network.
Some of the many features of &name-icinga; include:

listitem.para: Monitoring of host resources (CPU load, disk usage, etc.)
Simple plugin design that allows users to easily develop their own service checks
Ability to define network host hierarchy using "parent" hosts, allowing detection of and distinction between hosts that are down and those that are unreachable
Contact notifications when service or host problems occur and get resolved (via email, pager, or user-defined method)
Ability to define event handlers to be run during service or host events for proactive problem resolution
Support for implementing redundant monitoring hosts
Optional classic web interface for viewing current network status, notification and problem history, log file, etc.

Optional new Icinga web interface based on Icinga Core, IDOUtils, API using a modern and refreshed web 2.0 GUI showing current states, historical information, using cronks and filters, creating reports with multilanguage support

section.para:
As mentioned above you'll need a machine running &name-linux; or a Unix variant. If there is no precompiled version or if you want to compile from source you need a C compiler like gcc.
Some compilers may not be suitable. That includes the C compiler on HP-UX which is used to compile a new kernel. You may also want to have TCP/IP configured as most checks will require access via the network.
You are not required to use one of the web interfaces included with &name-icinga;. However, if you do decide to use them, you will need additional software:

listitem.para: Thomas Boutells gd library Version 1.6.3 or higher (required by the statusmap- and trends-CGIs)

You can check for new versions of &name-icinga; at &url-icinga;.

&name-icinga; is a fork of the well-known monitoring system &name-nagios;. Being 100% compatible with the internal structures of the latter &name-icinga; enables you to use all plugins and add-ons which were/are developed by several companies and the large community.
